content_form.text: Woman should plan to give birth at a facility due to risk factors
content_form.toaster_info_text:
Risk factors necessitating a facility birth:

- Age 17 or under

- Primigravida

- Parity 6 or higher

- Prior C-section

- Previous pregnancy complications: Heavy bleeding, Forceps or vacuum delivery, Convulsions, or 3rd degree tear

- Vaginal bleeding

 - Multiple fetuses

- Abnormal fetal presentation

- HIV+

- Wants IUD or tubal ligation following delivery
content_form.toaster_info_title: Woman should plan to give birth at a facility due to risk factors

content_form.label: Birth preparedness and complications readiness counseling
content_form.label_info_text:
This includes:

- Skilled birth attendant

- Labour and birth companion

- Location of the closest facility for birth and in case of complications

- Funds for any expenses related to birth and in case of complications

- Supplies and materials necessary to bring to the facility

- Support to look after the home and other children while she's away

- Transport to a facility for birth or in case of a complication

- Identification of compatible blood donors in case of complications
content_form.label_info_title: Birth preparedness and complications readiness counseling

content_form.label: Rh factor negative counseling
content_form.label_info_text:
Counseling:

- Woman is at risk of alloimmunisation if the baby's father is Rh positive or unknown

- Proceed with local protocol to investigate sensitization and the need for referral

- If non-sensitized, woman should receive anti-D prophylaxis postnatally if the baby is Rh positive

content_form.label: Intrapartum antibiotic to prevent early neonatal Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection counseling
content_form.label_info_text: Pregnant women with GBS colonization should receive intrapartum antibiotic administration to prevent early neonatal GBS infection.
content_form.label_info_title: Intrapartum antibiotic to prevent early neonatal Group B Streptococcus (GBS) infection counseling
